message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: How digital media drive affective polarization through partisan sorting
Paper Abstract: Politics has in recent decades entered an era of intense polarization. Explanations have implicated digital media, with the so-called echo chamber remaining a dominant causal hypothesis despite growing challenge by empirical evidence. This paper suggests that this mounting evidence provides not only reason to reject the echo chamber hypothesis but also the foundation for an alternative causal mechanism. To propose such a mechanism, the paper draws on the literatures on affective polarization, digital media, and opinion dynamics. From the affective polarization literature, we follow the move from seeing polarization as diverging issue positions to rooted in sorting: an alignment of differences which is effectively dividing the electorate into two increasingly homogeneous megaparties. To explain the rise in sorting, the paper draws on opinion dynamics and digital media research to present a model which essentially turns the echo chamber on its head: it is not isolation from opposing views that drives polarization but precisely the fact that digital media bring us to interact outside our local bubble. When individuals interact locally, the outcome is a stable plural patchwork of cross-cutting conflicts. By encouraging nonlocal interaction, digital media drive an alignment of conflicts along partisan lines, thus effacing the counterbalancing effects of local heterogeneity. The result is polarization, even if individual interaction leads to convergence. The model thus suggests that digital media polarize through partisan sorting, creating a maelstrom in which more and more identities, beliefs, and cultural preferences become drawn into an all-encompassing societal division.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Digital media":

## Overview

Digital media refers to mediums of digitized information broadcast through a screen and/or a speaker, including text, audio, video, and graphics transmitted over the internet for consumption on digital devices.

## Examples

Examples of digital media include software, digital images, web pages and websites, social media, digital data and databases, digital audio such as MP3, electronic documents and electronic books.

## Contrast with Traditional Media

Digital media often contrasts with print media, such as printed books, newspapers and magazines, and other traditional or analog media, such as photographic film, audio tapes or video tapes.

## Impact on Society

Combined with the Internet and personal computing, digital media has caused disruptive innovation in publishing, journalism, public relations, entertainment, education, commerce and politics. Additionally, digital media has posed new challenges to copyright and intellectual property laws, fostering an open content movement in which content creators voluntarily give up some or all of their legal rights to their work.

## Digital Transition

It is estimated that in the year 1986 less than 1% of the world's media storage capacity was digital and in 2007 it was already 94%. The year 2002 is assumed to be the year when human kind was able to store more information in digital than in analog media (the "beginning of the digital age").

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Affective polarization"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Group polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_polarization"},{"title":"Intellectual humility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellectual_humility"},{"title":"David Broockman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Broockman"},{"title":"Affective spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_disorders"},{"title":"Polarization (waves) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polarization_(waves)"},{"title":"Empathising–systemising theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empathizing-systemizing_theory"},{"title":"Polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polarization"},{"title":"Why We're Polarized - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Why_We're_Polarized"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about affective polarization:

## Definition

Affective polarization refers to the phenomenon where individuals' feelings and emotions towards members of their own political party or group become more positive, while their feelings towards members of the opposing party or group become more negative.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Consequences

This can lead to increased hostility and a lack of willingness to compromise or work together with people who hold different political views.(no content)Affective polarization may lead to aggressive attitudes and behaviors toward members of other ideological groups within the same country. Extreme affective polarization may even lead to dangerous consequences like societal disintegration and ideological sorting.

## Measurement and Trends

Affective polarization has been estimated via a variety of methods, including the Affective Polarization Scale and regression methods applied to social media data.(no content)Researchers have identified an increase in affective polarization among the United States electorate, and report that hostility and discrimination towards the opposing political party has increased dramatically over time.

## Reducing Affective Polarization

Affective polarization can be reduced by various means, such as feeling sadness together as a group (which often happens during Memorial Days). A high prevalence of respectful discussions with political others may also reduce affective polarization by increasing political tolerance and inter-party trust. High salience of a national common identity may also reduce affective polarization, as members of other parties are suddenly seen as in-group members.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Polarization politics"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"},{"title":"Conspiracy theories in United States politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theories_in_United_States_politics"},{"title":"Values, Voice and Virtue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Values,_Voice_and_Virtue:_The_New_British_Politics"},{"title":"Left–right political spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-Right_politics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of political polarization:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Manifestations of Polarization

Political scientists typically distinguish between two levels of political polarization: elite and mass, with "Elite polarization" focusing on the polarization of the political elites, like party organizers and elected officials, and "Mass polarization" focusing on the polarization of the masses, most often the electorate or general public.(no content)Mass polarization occurs when an electorate's attitudes towards political issues, policies, celebrated figures, or other citizens are neatly divided along party lines, and at the extreme, each camp questions the moral legitimacy of the other, viewing the opposing camp and its policies as an existential threat.

## Contemporary Polarization Trends

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases in polarization during the 2000s onwards, and according to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions are at record highs as of 2022.

## Related Concepts

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike, whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of political polarization:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Manifestations of Polarization

Political scientists typically distinguish between two levels of political polarization: elite and mass, with "Elite polarization" focusing on the polarization of the political elites, like party organizers and elected officials, and "Mass polarization" focusing on the polarization of the masses, most often the electorate or general public.(no content)Mass polarization occurs when an electorate's attitudes towards political issues, policies, celebrated figures, or other citizens are neatly divided along party lines, and at the extreme, each camp questions the moral legitimacy of the other, viewing the opposing camp and its policies as an existential threat.

## Contemporary Polarization Trends

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases in polarization during the 2000s onwards, and according to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions are at record highs as of 2022.

## Related Concepts

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike, whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party.

Web search results for query: "Opinion dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical models of social learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_models_of_social_learning"},{"title":"Sznajd model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sznajd_model"},{"title":"Social physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_physics"},{"title":"Eitan Tadmor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eitan_Tadmor"},{"title":"Jerusalem Institute for Market Studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerusalem_Institute_for_Market_Studies"},{"title":"DeGroot learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeGroot_learning"},{"title":"Public opinion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_opinion"},{"title":"Group dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_dynamics"},{"title":"Opinion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion"},{"title":"Opinion journalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_journalism"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Opinion Dynamics**:

## Definition and Overview

Opinion dynamics is the study of how opinions evolve in social networks through mathematical modeling.(no content)In these models, people (agents) hold beliefs or opinions about the state of the world, and learn about it through observation or communication with others. Models of social learning formalize these interactions to describe how agents process information received from their friends in the social network.

## Key Research Questions

Main questions in the literature include whether social learning effectively aggregates scattered information (i.e., whether the consensus belief matches the true state of the world), and how effective media sources, politicians, and prominent agents can be in influencing the entire network's belief formation.

## Major Models

**DeGroot Learning:** The DeGroot model, introduced in 1974, is one of the first models for describing how humans interact in a social network. According to it, each agent takes a weighted average of their neighbors' opinions at each step to update their own belief.

**Sznajd Model:** The Sznajd model (also called "United We Stand, Divided We Fall") was introduced in 2000 to understand opinion dynamics. It states that if two people share the same opinion, their neighbors will start to agree with them, but if adjacent persons disagree, their neighbors start to argue with them.

## Related Applications

Research includes interdisciplinary programs on self-collective dynamics with applications to flocking and opinion dynamics.

Based on the search results, here's information about echo chambers:

## Definition

An echo chamber is formed when users come across beliefs that magnify or reinforce their thoughts and form a group of like-minded users in a closed system.

## How Echo Chambers Function

Echo chambers function by circulating existing views without encountering opposing views, potentially leading to three cognitive biases: correlation neglect, selection bias and confirmation bias.(no content)Participants in online discussions may find their opinions constantly echoed back to them, which reinforces their individual belief systems due to the declining exposure to other's opinions.

## Online Mechanisms

Social platforms and online media outlets have established personalized algorithms intended to cater specific information to individuals' online feeds, and this mediated spread of information through online networks causes a risk of an algorithmic filter bubble.

## Effects

Echo chambers may increase social and political polarization and extremism. However, some studies have suggested that the effects of echo chambers are weaker than often assumed. For instance, most people do consume news from various sources, while around 8% consume media with low diversity.

Web search results for query: "Partisan sorting"

Links: [{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Matthew Levendusky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Levendusky"},{"title":"Partial sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_sorting"},{"title":"Category:Politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Politics"},{"title":"Soviet partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Partisans"},{"title":"Cook Partisan Voting Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cook_Partisan_Voting_Index"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Jewish partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewish_partisans"},{"title":"Partisan (politics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_(politics)"}]

Here are the search results for "Partisan sorting":

## Definition

Partisan sorting is an effect in politics in which voters sort themselves into parties that match their ideology.(no content)Partisan sorting is distinct from political polarization, which is where partisans subscribe to increasingly extreme positions.

## Key Characteristics

Partisan sorting refers to the extent to which the electorate "sorts" or identifies with a party based on their ideological, racial, religious, gender, or other demographic characteristics.

## How It Works: An Example

The gap between the Democratic Party and Republican Party on views towards immigrants strengthening the country with hard work and talents has widened from a 2-point gap in 1994 to a 42-point gap in 2017. A reasonable explanation is that of partisan sorting: those who are pro-immigrant shifted into the Democratic party and immigration-restrictions have shifted towards the Republican party.

## Historical Context

Previously, many liberals identified as Republicans and many conservatives identified as Democrats. More recently, the parties have become more ideologically pure and encouraged people to think of themselves in that way as well. Thus, voters have been "sorting" into Democrats and Republicans and eliminated much of the middle ground that existed in previous generations.

## Scholarly Debate

One school of thought led by Morris Fiorina concludes most of the change comes from ideological partisan sorting, with polarization having little effect or being solely limited to political elites.(no content)Conversely, another school of thought led by Alan Abramowitz challenges this and says sorting itself is a reflection of political polarization and that both the elites and the public have become increasingly polarized.

## Geographic Sorting

A form of partisan sorting is geographic sorting, which alleges that people decide to move into communities that match their party. Research by political scientists in 2012 found that people prefer to relocate to areas with copartisans, though it was unsure if it was a central or secondary factor.

Research by political scientists in 2012 found that people prefer to relocate to areas with copartisans, though it was unsure if it was a central or secondary factor.

Web search results for query: "Partisan sorting"

Links: [{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Matthew Levendusky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Levendusky"},{"title":"Partial sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_sorting"},{"title":"Category:Politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Politics"},{"title":"Soviet partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Partisans"},{"title":"Cook Partisan Voting Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cook_Partisan_Voting_Index"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Jewish partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewish_partisans"},{"title":"Partisan (politics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_(politics)"}]

Here are the search results for "Partisan sorting":

## Definition

Partisan sorting is an effect in politics in which voters sort themselves into parties that match their ideology.(no content)Partisan sorting is distinct from political polarization, which is where partisans subscribe to increasingly extreme positions.

## Key Characteristics

Partisan sorting refers to the extent to which the electorate "sorts" or identifies with a party based on their ideological, racial, religious, gender, or other demographic characteristics.

## How It Works: An Example

The gap between the Democratic Party and Republican Party on views towards immigrants strengthening the country with hard work and talents has widened from a 2-point gap in 1994 to a 42-point gap in 2017. A reasonable explanation is that of partisan sorting: those who are pro-immigrant shifted into the Democratic party and immigration-restrictions have shifted towards the Republican party.

## Historical Context

Previously, many liberals identified as Republicans and many conservatives identified as Democrats. More recently, the parties have become more ideologically pure and encouraged people to think of themselves in that way as well. Thus, voters have been "sorting" into Democrats and Republicans and eliminated much of the middle ground that existed in previous generations.

## Scholarly Debate

One school of thought led by Morris Fiorina concludes most of the change comes from ideological partisan sorting, with polarization having little effect or being solely limited to political elites.(no content)Conversely, another school of thought led by Alan Abramowitz challenges this and says sorting itself is a reflection of political polarization and that both the elites and the public have become increasingly polarized.

## Geographic Sorting

A form of partisan sorting is geographic sorting, which alleges that people decide to move into communities that match their party. Research by political scientists in 2012 found that people prefer to relocate to areas with copartisans, though it was unsure if it was a central or secondary factor.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete

**Paper Type:** Contribution

The paper proposes a novel causal mechanism explaining how digital media drive affective polarization through partisan sorting, challenging the dominant echo chamber hypothesis.

**Extracted Entities (6 total):**

1. **Political polarization** (concept) - proposes: The paper introduces a new mechanism for polarization emergence through partisan sorting
2. **Partisan sorting** (concept) - proposes: Central to the paper's explanation of how digital media create political divisions
3. **Affective polarization** (concept) - uses: Draws on this literature to focus on emotional divisions rather than policy divergence
4. **Echo chamber (media)** (concept) - uses: Challenges this dominant hypothesis with empirical evidence and alternative theory
5. **Digital media** (tool) - uses: Examines how these platforms facilitate non-local interaction patterns
6. **Mathematical models of social learning** (method) - uses: Foundation for the opinion dynamics framework underlying the model

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED
- All 6 triples validated successfully
- Paper satisfies requirements: has multiple "proposes" relations (contribution) and at least one "uses" (builds on existing work)
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct

Sources:
- [Political polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization)
- [Partisan sorting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting)
- [Echo chamber (media)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media))
- [Digital media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_media)
- [Mathematical models of social learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_models_of_social_learning)
